THE COUNTRY AND ITS RECENT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT HISTORICAL SETTING 1.1 A Painful Transition. Georgia was the first of the non-Baltic states to declare independence from the Former Soviet Union (FSU) on April 9, 1991. Before 1991, Georgia had a relatively prosperous economy, specializing in exports of agricultural products (almost exclusively to the other Soviet republics), in the extraction of metals, and in the assembly of a wide range of industrial products. Income per capita was just below 3,000 rubles (or about US$1,600), placing Georgia in midway among the 15 former Soviet republics. 1.2 In the years directly following its independence, Georgia suffered one of the sharpest economic declines of all the FSU states. Officially estimated GDP in 1994 was less than 15 percent of its 1989 level. Electricity consumption - often considered as a better proxy for real GDP in transition economies - is estimated to have fallen by 55 percent in the same period. The decline in government revenues as a percentage of GDP (the tax ratio), a consequence of the erosion in the government's authority and ability to mobilize revenues, was even more striking. From 30% in 1991, the tax ratio fell to 11% in 1992, and collapsed to 3.7 % in 1995. Huge financial imbalances led to hyperinflation (at rates of up to 70% per month until the second half of 1994) and a sharp depreciation in the value of domestic currency. In December 1993, the Georgian coupon was worth less than I% of its value in January of the same year. 1.3 A Remarkable Turnaround. Acting against this background, the government focused on economic management in early 1994 and arrested the contraction in trade and economic activity. Although extensive data on the current level of economic activity is unavailable, there are indications that Georgia's economic situation has improved significantly in recent months. With the successful introduction of the country's new currency (the Lari, introduced on September 25, 1995), major steps toward macroeconomics stabilization were taken and a sharp reduction of the fiscal deficit, from 26.2% of GDP in 1993 to 4.5% in 1995, was achieved. While the economic situation remains precarious, stabilization measures have already brought considerable results: the monthly inflation rate fell from an average of 60 percent in the first three quarters of 1994 to an average of 2% between October 1994 and April 1995; the inflation rate for 1996 was 13.9%. Gross official reserves have been rebuilt and most of the bilateral debt has been rescheduled. Moreover, substantial structural reforms (subsidies reduction, price liberalization, civil service restructuring, fiscal administration improvement, etc.) have begun. After four years of continuous decline, growth resumed with total GDP growing by 2.4% in 1995 and 10.5% in 1996 - a turnaround unique among transition economies.

The downturn in the state-controlled economy and runaway inflation until mid-1994 have inflicted painful social costs on the population. Shrinking resources have complicated the Government's efforts to maintain law and order and to preserve an adequate social safety net for the poor. By 1995, GDP per capita had shrunk to US$4 10, the second lowest level among the FSU countries, placing the majority of the Georgian population under the official poverty line. Expenditures on health and education declined from 12 percent of GDP in 1991 to 2 percent in 1994 (although expenditures in the health sector appear to be rising again) - a decline of over 90 percent in real terms. Life expectancy. for both men and women, has declined in recent years, while the age-adjusted mortality rate has risen by 18 percent. Net school enrollment has likewise fallen by 11 percent in the last three years. 1.6 There are, however, positive indications that Georgia's strong traditional family structure has cushioned the impact of declining social services. While economic figures suggest extreme hardship, casual observation suggests an upturn in the overall activity. The informal sector is growing and in contrast to reports from other FSU countries, rural incomes have held up fairly well. The area of cultivated land in 1995 significantly exceeded that of previous years and in key cities, the traffic, the number of shops open for business, and the availability of goods in markets indicate rapidly improving trends. 1.7 Municipal Infrastructure. With an economy under severe stress and an erosion in public confidence, physical infrastructure and municipal services have been neglected and are deteriorating rapidly. While trying to cope with the current situation, the municipal sector still operates largely under the organizational and policy structure of earlier days.
 3 1.8 In approximate terms, more than half (55%) of Georgia's population lives in urban settlements. Tbilisi, the capital and largest city in the country, has a population of 1.5 million and makes up 27 percent of the total population of Georgia and 51 percent of its urban population. The remaining six largest urban settlements include: Kutaisi (240,000), Rustavi (156,000), Batumi (137,000), Zugdidi (129,000), Poti (75,000) and Gori (60,000). Together with Tbilisi, their population makes up approximately 75% of the urban population of Georgia. While the armed conflicts of recent years have caused major changes in the geographical distribution of the population, no reliable information on migration trends is yet available. However, there have been two conflicting trends. It is thought that declining income levels led to an exodus of city dwellers to rural areas. This trend was probably outweighed, however, by the influx of the 300,000 refugees to the principal cities. B. INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 1.9 Present Conditions. Today, the main concern with respect to local government in Georgia involves its inherent institutional weakness. The social turmoil, political instability and economic crisis of the past six years have caused the central government to postpone sub- national administrative reform and proceed - at least temporarily - with rule by decree. At present, nearly all local government officials are appointed by the center; as a result, local government autonomy does not exist in principle. Substantial freedom of action for these centrally appointed local officials has existed in practice, however, because of the weakness of the central government and its inability to maintain tight control over the various localities 1.10 The symptoms of weakness common to local government institutions in most of the FSU are particularly acute in Georgia, because of the mutually reinforcing effects of recent economic recession, war and general breakdown of civil order. Among the most significant of these problems are: (a) little accountability to residents because there are no mechanisms allowing citizens to monitor the actions of local govemment, nor is there any formal procedure to voice civic discontent or call for the removal of poorly performing officials. Ultimately, those who pay for municipal services, either through taxation or direct fees, have no representation in municipal rule; (b) local officials are not bound by systematic internal regulations, but rather only by guidelines set out by the centrally appointed official; and (c) inefficiencies in the management of the municipality's administrative functions with overstaffing and unclear allocation of responsibility among local officials. As a result, decision-making and implementation are largely left to the individual initiative of municipal staff. 1.11 Departing Structure. Until recently, the structure and function of local government in Georgia was based on provisions specified in a number of Presidential (formerly known as the Head of State) decrees which were intended to carry the country through a transitional phase eventually leading to local elections (tentatively scheduled for Autumn 1997 or early 1998). From 1992 until the end of 1995, institutional adjustments in the local government sector were aimed almost exclusively at the improvement of resource allocation and did not affect the basic structure inherited from the Soviet period. 1.12 Among the various decrees produced by the Head of State's Office since 1993, the Provisional Statement "About Local Management Bodies in Georgia" (Decree No. 362, September 16, 1995) had the single biggest implication for local government in Georgia. This decree consolidates previously uncoordinated temporary legislation into a comprehensive format

The decision was introduced "in order to further improve the state management system, to create the basis for self- control provided by the Georgian Constitution, to strengthen the economic basis of state management local agencies and to carry out progressive radical economic reforms" (Article 1). On the wave of gradual economic recovery, since the end of 1995 the Government and the Parliament have operated toward fulfilling their specific constitutional obligation to implement local self- government reform. Article 4.2 of the Constitution, in fact, reads as follows: "Georgian citizens shall arrange local affairs through self-government, without the violation of national sovereignty. The rule of establishment of local self-government bodies, their powers and relationship with state bodies will be determined by organic law". Through the concerted efforts of the Government's Regional Policy and Management Service (RPMS) and the Parliament, Georgia has made considerable progress toward the establishment of the legal and regulatory framework. Presently, the proposed new Law on Local Self-Government and Administration (recently approved by Parliament and now ready to be countersigned by the President) and the State Program for Municipal Development (SPMD), to be discussed and approved by the Cabinet before the end of July, 1997, prepare the ground for a more modem, democratic and efficient system of sub-national territorial administration. In addition to the importance of each document within the framework of the country's administrative and financial decentralization, the consistency and potential synergy between the both approaches denotes a high level of cooperation between Government and the Parliament, thus warranting cautious optimism with regard to the pace and effectiveness of future reform. The Government's reform plan was summarized in the recent Municipal Sector Policy Letter (Annex 1). The Government program confirms that local elections are to take place by June 1998 at the latest. 1.15 To implement the municipal development program, the President has signed a Decree No 105 "Regarding the Approval of the Regional Policy and Management Service of the President of Georgia". (February 14, 1997). This new regulation establishes the RPMS as the central coordination unit at the government level in charge of ensuring political oversight of the decentralization process. C. MUNICIPAL FINANCE 1.17 Georgia's 1995 tax ratio (est. at 3.7) was among the lowest in the world. The implications of this low tax ratio are substantial for municipalities, because just under half (47%) of all central government revenues in 1995 were passed on to municipalities. Despite this, however, revenues - in relative terms - of the principal Georgian cities have improved considerably over the last two to three years. The growth in revenues for the City of Tbilisi from 1993 to 1995 illustrates municipal revenue growth accounting for more than a quarter (27%) of the total and more than half (51 %) of the urban population respectively. The recent changes in the composition of revenues as well as their volume have been dramatic. Total revenues, including loans and subsidy receipts, increased more than 7 times from 1993 to 1995. Declining reliance on borrowing and central government subsidies over the period meant that tax revenue and other receipts increased almost twelve fold, however. In fact, the increase in Tbilisi's revenues was particularly marked from 1994 to 1995. While total revenues increased more than sevenfold over the whole period, they merely doubled between 1993 and 1994. The interpretation of these spectacular rates of growth should be moderated by the realization that they do not reflect an economic boom so much as recovery from a prior period of almost total economic breakdown. Major Sources of Municipal Revenues 1.18 Taxes. Georgia's current tax system was authorized in the Law on the Basics of the Tax System in Georgia (December 21, 1993), in which the importance of local government autonomy was clearly established, with the assertion of the right to levy local taxes. Principal taxes are allocated to one level of government or the other, or are sometimes shared, with the base and rates being determined by the central government. Among national taxes, the Value Added Tax (VAT), customs duties and land taxes are shared between central and local governments in differing proportions. Proceeds from the enterprise profits tax are allocated entirely to local governments, while excise duties are retained by the central government. In 1995, 47.3% of total "national" tax revenues was transferred to local budgets. 1.19 Intergovernmental Tax-Sharing Arrangements. The sharing arrangements for these "national" taxes are based on the derivation principle: revenues are returned to the areas in which they were collected. The geographic allocation of these revenues has shifted several times with changing economic conditions. Initially, for instance, the VAT sharing arrangements gave cities with a substantial industrial base (e.g., Rustavi) a 10% share of VAT revenues as opposed to the 30% share received by other localities. This was an attempt at equalization by offsetting the
 6 higher yield of the VAT in the cities with a richer tax base. As more cities ran into budgetary difficulties, the number of those receiving 30% of VAT revenues was increased. In 1995, the central government planned to redistribute 2.2 million Lari from local budgets of better-off communities, but only 0.3 million Lari were actually made available for transfer. 1.20 Local Taxes. In the Tax Law of December 21, 1993, mayors were given the right to raise "local" levies and fees such as trading licenses, parking fees and specific sales taxes such as taxes on vehicle sales. The list of potential local taxes authorized (i.e, presumptive taxes, local sales and excise taxes, local tariffs, land and asset taxes, etc.) is quite extensive and does not appear to be confined to the usual variety of minor fees or taxes which have been allocated to local governments in many CIS and Eastern European countries. Although each tax must be approved by the President's office, many of the taxes currently levied by individual municipalities have substantial revenue potential. Furthermore, a most important general provision of this law allows mayors to impose "special purpose levies.... for the improvement of municipal territories, police, and other purposes". Extensive and, for the most part, constructive use has been made of this provision by the principal cities. Municipal Expenditures 1.21 Although the available expenditure classifications are vague and do not provide clear linkages to specific service categories, the 1995 level of local expenditures in Georgian municipalities appear to vary dramatically from a high of US$28 per capita per year in Poti, to a low of US$8 in Batumi. Tbilisi is at a mid-range with US$15. Based on data received from the principal cities for 1995, the major expenditures are: maintenance of communal services (lighting, drainage, roads, cleaning, etc.), education, health, and subsidies for urban transport and housing. Currently, the level of expenditures in the social sectors is significant and probably equivalent to the funding provided from the central budget for similar services. 1.22 Cost recovery for urban services was not one of the goals of the former command economy in Georgia. Utility charges to consumers were extremely low - about 2-3% of costs in Tbilisi, for instance. Prices did not serve the same regulating function as in market economies and domestic consumers of local public utility services were subsidized both directly and indirectly; directly by municipal subsidies and indirectly by cross-subsidies paid for by price discrimination against industrial and commercial users. Prospects for cost recovery in infrastructure services, together with all municipal revenues, seem to have increased with the turnaround of the Georgian economy in 1995, Municipal Investment Financing 1.23 Current investments at the municipal level are negligible and borrowing capacity is limited. Local governments do have collateral for loans, not only in the form of property that they own, but implicitly through future streams of utility charges or transfers from the central government. However, the weak state of the financial system in Georgia restricts borrowing by even the most creditworthy local governments. There is no mechanism to lend to local governments for investments in infrastructure and the central government does not fulfill the role of intermediary between domestic/international funding sources and local governments. This complete lack of municipal investment financing sources contributes to justifying the present proposed project.
 7 D. BANK EXPERIENCE AND STRATEGY 1.24 Bank strategy and projects. The principal lessons learned from over a decade of Bank experience in lending for municipal development, worldwide, include the importance of: (a) strong and consistent central government support for the principles of financially sound municipal development; (b) intensive project supervision; (c) project design that is simple and that, at the sub-project level, reflects the needs and desires of municipalities participating in the project; (d) reasonable eligibility criteria for participation; (e) need for central government assistance in the identification and preparation of municipal sub-projects; and (f) simple and efficient procedures for sub-project review and approval. Those lessons have been taken into account in the design of the proposed project. 1.25 Bank experience in Georgia. IDA's credit experience dates only from FY94. However, strong future potential of the local government sector in Georgia has been confirmed at every stage of the Bank's assistance effort so far. The Municipal Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (the IDA Board of Directors approved the US$18 million credit on November 9, 1994) which was identified and prepared rapidly in response to the country's immediate needs in the aftermath of the civil war, is nearing the end of a successful implementation. The project has provided the indispensable country-knowledge for the preparation of the following ongoing activities: (i) a Social Investment Fund Project, due for appraisal in May-June, 1997; (ii) a Water Supply and Sanitation Project, which was recently identified and is mainly intended to target sector-specific needs in Tbilisi and at the Gardabani Waste Water Treatment Plant; (iii) an IDF-financed Cultural Heritage Initiative, whose implementation is beginning under strong Government support, following a highly participatory identification process for six pilot sites; and (iv) the Legal Framework and Municipal Database IDF Grant approved recently. 1.26 In addition to the municipal sector activities, the following operations were approved by the Board: an Institutional Building Credit of US$ 10.1 million equivalent was approved on July 5, 1994; a Rehabilitation Credit of US$75 million equivalent was approved on March 30, 1995; a Transportation Credit of US$12 million equivalent was approved on January 6, 1996; a Structural Adjustment Credit of US$60 million equivalent and an associated TA. Credit of US$4.8 million equivalent were approved on April 18, 1996; and a Health Credit of US$14 million equivalent was approved on April 25, 1996, and an Agriculture Project (US$15 million). Although the portfolio is increasing rapidly, limited implementation experience was gained in these various sectors. 1.27 The overall implementation performance of the first operations is considered highly satisfactory by both the Government and the Bank. However, experiences from these activities have shown that four key factors can help facilitate project implementation: (i) simplicity of project design; (ii) active Government participation in project preparation; (iii) support in project management for agencies inexperienced in implementing Bank projects; and, (iv) intensive supervision efforts by the Bank. These lessons have been taken into consideration in the design of this project.

RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT Country Assistance Strategy Objectives Supported by the Program 1.28 The proposed IDA assistance program is consistent with the limited Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), as discussed by the Board of Directors during the presentation of the Rehabilitation Credit on March 30, 1995. A full CAS is currently under preparation and Board review is scheduled in September, 1997. The proposed project is consistent with the priority objectives of the CAS by: (a) improving the mobilization of local resources; (b) developing institutional capacity for better expenditure management at the central and local levels; (c) improving the management of public assets, critical for private sector development - particularly through improved maintenance; and (d) reducing poverty. Relevance of the Municipal Sector 1.29 The quality of municipal infrastructure and service provision helps determine a country's success or failure in diversifying production, expanding trade, reducing poverty and improving environmental conditions. Georgia's future economic recovery and its overall development into a market-oriented economy will largely depend on its ability to establish dynamic local administrations. As the country gradually emerges from years of political, social and economic turmoil, the many legitimate demands of enterprises and households - long left on hold - should be expected to gradually influence the government's agenda. As a consequence, Georgia is already facing a well-known fiscal dilemma: How to generate sufficient public investment without incurring excessive public debt? Centralized control of aggregate public debt alone is not conducive to an optimal level of public investment. On the other hand, the partial transfer of responsibility for infrastructure investments/maintenance and provision of communal services to local governments can help optimize resource allocation while under fiscal constraints. Government Strategy 1.30 Local governments, whose overall revenues more than doubled between 1994 and 1995, contributed significantly to the above improvements and will be expected to contribute more in the future, as greater authority for managing many public services is planned to be devolved to them. From the consolidation of civil and democratic life in towns and villages to the provision of basic communal services (i.e., water supply, public transport, etc.), municipalities are bound to assume a leading role. In response to the growing importance of local governments in the economic and political life of the country, the Government has undertaken a broad sector reform effort aimed at attaining greater decentralization as defined by the principle of subsidiary (i.e., any administrative or economic responsibility should be delegated to the lowest level of government capable of discharging it effectively). 1.31 Through its Municipal Development Program, the Government has decided to implement a comprehensive decentralization strategy consistent with Georgia's long-term economic and administrative needs. As stated in its Municipal Sector Policy Letter signed in May 1997, this would "...be achieved through: (i) legal and regulatory framework which would clearly define the state and municipal property; (ii) promoting the fiscal and economic independence of local government... ,(iii) improved service delivery for local population ... ;(iv) improved utilization of local resources for the development of local social infrastructure; (v)
 9 establishment of the Municipal Development Fund ..; and (vi) development of information systems..." (Annex 1). The culmination of this reform effort will be reached with Georgia's first local elections, scheduled before June 1998. The local government elections will constitute another major milestone in the country's overall democratization process. Specific Sector Issues to be Addressed by the Project and Strategic Choices 1.32 The proposed MDDP responds to an overall strategic framework defined by: (a) the Government's decentralization policy; (b) the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy; and (c) recent sector work. Consistent with its development objectives, the program will target the following issues/themes: (a) Strengthening/management capacity-building of the local government sector. Like most other countries of the FSU, Georgia faces considerable problems related to the institutional weakness of public administration, both central and local. While slight improvements in the quality of municipal management have become visible in recent months (for example in Kutaisi, the country's second largest municipality), the present ability of local governments to effectively address the needs of the population in terms of basic services and administrative functions gives rise to concern. (b) Promoting greater transparency and accountability in local governance. Constituencies should come to consider municipal policy as an inextricable component of the local community's needs and ambitions. By establishing strict standards of public information and consultation as a prerequisite for access to the MDF, the MDDP could significantly contribute to attaining greater transparency and accountability in municipal governance. (c) Creating a conducive environment for local revenue mobilization. The project could lay the groundwork for the country's envisaged general fiscal reform. By helping to bridge the gap between municipal revenues and expenditures through strict eligibility criteria for credit under the municipal contract, the MDDP could prepare the ground for Georgia's successful fiscal reform, which the Government and the Parliament recognize as a prerequisite for longer term economic stabilization. (d) Improvement of the level and quality of municipal service provision through better maintenance and infrastructure. The important objective of improved service delivery could be achieved through: (i) focused and explicit performance evaluation criteria; (ii) introduction of competitive principles among service providers, be they municipally owned or private; and, (iii) phasing out of subsidies and gradual but decisive enforcement of cost-recovery in all municipal services. 1.33 The proposed MDDP attempts to best integrate the particular emphasis that the Government is placing on the effective restructuring of the municipal system. While it is the first step of an iterative process, this assistance program focuses on the priorities identified as essential to improve the efficiency of local governments. The program will evolve over the medium and long term, incorporating the progress made and learning from the difficulties encountered, all within the broader context of the Country Assistance Strategy.

The symptoms of weakness common to local government institutions in most of the FSU are particularly acute in Georgia, because of the mutually reinforcing effects of recent economic recession, infrastructure decay, war and the general breakdown of civil order. The most significant problems specific to local governments include: (a) a little accountability to residents because of a lack of mechanisms allowing constituents to monitor the actions of local officials; (b) a lack of systematic internal regulations (most local government units operate on the basis of central government directives; (c) inefficiencies in the management of local government functions, caused mainly by an unclear allocation of responsibilities among local officials and between units, as well as overstaffing. 2. The Government recognizes that any successful strategy aimed at revitalizing the economy and social texture of Georgia cannot exclude the establishment of a representative and modem local government sector. This principle is explicitly upheld in the Constitution, which states (article 2.4): "Georgian Citizens shall arrange local affairs through self-government, without the violation of national sovereignty. The rule of establishment of local self-government bodies, their powers and relationships with state bodies will be determined by organic law. Main Objectives of Institutional Reform 3. In view of the above, the Government of Georgia has decided to implement a comprehensive decentralization strategy consistent with Georgia's long-term economic and administrative needs. The strategy is based on the Municipal Development Program approved by the Government of Georgia and its main objectives are described below: Solving the issues of local importance through self-governance, based on self-organization of the local society. This objective could be achieved through: (i) creation of the legal and regulatory framework in conducive for the establishment and development of local self-governance, in accordance with the Constitution of Georgia;
 MDDP 39 Annex I Page 2 of 3 (ii) definition of the nature and scope of the rights and responsibilities assigned to local government bodies; (iii) promotion of greater transparency and accountability in local governance; and (iv) clear definition of the institutional and economic relationships between the local govemment bodies and the central government. Development of local social-economic infrastructure, improvement of social services and social protection. This could be achieved through: (i) legal and regulatory framework which would clearly define the state and municipal property; (ii) promoting the fiscal and economic independence of the local government bodies and creating in conducive environment for the local revenue mobilization; (iii) improved service delivery for the population, by introducing competition among service providers, assessment criteria and better targeted municipal service investments; (iv) improved utilization of local resources for the development of local social infrastructure; (iv) establishment of the Municipal Development Fund which within the framework of the Municipal Contract will finance the development of local social-economic infrastructure; and (v) development of information systems at the local government bodies and their integration into the state information system database. Progress to Date on Institutional Reform 4. The Government and the Parliament of Georgia have already undertaken important steps toward a comprehensive reform of the structure and functions of subnational governance in the country. For the municipal sector development the most important one was the Presidential Decree No. 362 of September 16, 1995, which approved a temporary regulation "on Local State Administration Body". The above charter laid the foundation for the transition from centralized system to self-governance. The first result of this process was the recent preparation of the draft law "On Local Self-govemance and Administration", which currently is being discussed at the respective parliamentary committee. S. The draft law above will be discussed in the Parliament in May-June, 1997 and its adoption will be the first step towards the introduction of a comprehensive legal framework for local governance. The next step implies the preparation of municipal and local elections, definition of the self-governance status, preparation of the Laws on Municipal Property, before the end of 1997. 6. Since the jurisdiction of Georgia is not completely restored, implementation of the State- Territorial Arrangement reform is pending. Nevertheless the Government has already an established strategy for this reform, which is aimed at the definition of the roles and functions of the regional (highest) level of local administration and differentiation of the competence spheres among different governance levels, based on the principles outlined in the Constitution. The reform period (2 years) for the implementation of self-govemance and state-territorial arrangement is considered by the Government as a transition period. Within this period the main elements of the democratic local administration should be implemented. Implementation Strategy 7. In consideration of the above, the Government of Georgia will use the proposed Municipal Decentralization and Development Program (MDDP) to support the implementation of the
 MDDP 40 Annex 1 Page 3 of 3 initial phase of the municipal sector reforms. The Government commits itself to the following actions/programs: a) To adopt the State Municipal Development Program not later than July 1997; (b) To preserve the momentum of the current legal reform. This will include, among other actions, the following: (i) presentation of the envisaged new laws to Parliament (including any revision to the budget law implemented to account for new local government legislation) based on a realistic timetable; (ii) transmission to the Bank of all newly approved legislation on local governance; (iii) to held the local administration elections ASAP and not later than June 1998; (c) To introduce - in a progressive and timely manner - the institutional and regulatory framework required for the implementation of new legislation on local government. (d) To adopt, in consultation with the Bank, a viable and transparent mechanisms for the transfer of central budgetary resources to municipalities targeted for investments under the Municipal Development Fund (MDF) component of the proposed MDDP. This will also entail the introduction of clear procedures for the establishment of Municipal Contracts between the central government and potential beneficiary municipalities outlining the overall objectives of the latter over a period of years. (e) To provide - through such legal, institutional and financial measures as may become appropriate over time - the explicit overarching objectives of the proposed MDDP, namely: (i) assisting in institutional capacity - building toward the implementation of the decentralization process at the central and local government level; (ii) promoting the improvement of financial and administrative management as well as municipal investment; (iii) supporting urgent local investments; (iv) generating employment opportunities; and, (v) creating an environment conducive to private sector involvement in the municipal sector. The Government of Georgia looks forward to this important development strategy, whose impact - in terms of improved governance and more reliable service delivery - will be felt by a large segment of Georgia's population.  MDDP 60 Annex 7 Page I of 2 BANK EXPERIENCE IN MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT 1. The proposed project will benefit from the many lessons learned over more than a decade of Bank experience in municipal development, worldwide. From the earliest Bank-financed municipal development projects, the Operations Evaluation Department (OED) found that a strong commitment from the central government to the principles of financially sound municipal development, and to ongoing reforms, is essential for project success. Supervision, intensive during project start-up, and consistent throughout project implementation was also found to increase the likelihood of success. 2. From the Brazil: Parana Market Towns Project (Ln 2343-BR), OED identified several key factors contributing to project success, including: (a) Local government support for the project's local level operations (b) Small subprojects of relatively simple design, for which municipalities themselves, through community participation, had expressed a desire. (c) A competent, motivated team in charge of project management at the local level. (d) Risk management by simultaneous initiation of subprojects in a number of towns, thus reducing the average risks of delayed project execution as well as providing additional political support. 3. The ongoing Brazil Municipal Development Project in Parana and Rio Grande do Sul States (Ln 3100-BR and Ln 3129-BR, respectively) have shown that eligibility criteria (such as the preparation of detailed financial and institutional development plan ) for participation in municipal development program should be clear and not excessively rigid. Clear and flexible eligibility criteria foster increased participation and, at the same time, prevent delays in projects start-up and disbursements 4. In addition to the lessons learned from completed Bank projects in municipal development, several Bank reviews provide lessons from both completed and ongoing projects germane to the proposed project An Infrastructure and Urban Development Department (INURD) review of Bank lending for municipal finance operations emphasizes that the primary objective of municipal finance should not be simply the increased extraction of tax revenues for municipal use. Instead, municipal finance operations must be designed as part of a broader effort to increase the accountability of the public sector, through decentralization of control to the local level, and through the creation of means and incentives that both allow and encourage local governments to respond to local priorities. Thus, successful municipal finance reform must start, not with increasing municipal revenues, but with improving the effectiveness and efficiency of municipal service delivery. 5. In conjunction with this objective, a Europe, Middle East and North Africa Regional study ( Decentralization and Reform of the State - EMENA, The World Bank, September 1992) identified direct user charges and betterment taxes as the preferred sources of municipal services, as these confront final beneficiaries directly with the costs of municipal services, as well as promoting accountability in resource allocation.
 MDDP 61 Annex 7 Page 2 of 2 6. The INURD and EMENA reviews recommend that: (a) The primary interlocutors for municipal finance reformn operations be at the national level, as the impact and sustainability of any local level reform depend on the incentives provided by the national government to the municipal governments; (b) Technical assistance for municipal finance projects be explicitly action-oriented. In the past, technical assistance often served as a substitute for reform; policy confrontations were avoided by defining the policy context of projects solely in terms of abstract studies; and (c) a strong central agency in charge of the decentralization process has been key to the success of past reforms. 7. The Bank experience shows that in the context of municipal finance reform, the Bank strives to foster accountability and transparency, to encourage the clear identification of responsibilities at each level of government, and to confront consumers with the real costs of the services they enjoy. All such actions usually have clear short-term political costs and only longer- term, intangible benefits. Because of the resulting political difficulties inherent in municipal finance reform, the Bank must: (a) Plan for long term, multiple project investments and sustained policy dialogue with the central government; (b) Concentrate its resources on countries where institutional development and decentralization are already underway; and (c) Devote more staff resources to municipal development operations than it has in the past. 8. Finally, a review of Bank experience in the provision of technical assistance makes the following recommendations: (a) Support upstream institutional development work in selected municipalities or regions; (b) Assess the absorptive capacity of entities involved in institutional development to minimize the risk of over-ambitious project design; (c) Promote multiple approaches to, and instruments for, the support of complex institutional development reforms; and (d) Undertake periodic institutional assessments to examine the functions, strengths, and weaknesses of, and linkages among, relevant institutions, as well as their legal and regulatory framework as well as their performance incentives. The design of the MDDP project is trying to integrate all relevant lessons learned by the Bank in the municipal sector over the last ten year.

 MDDP 66 Annex 10 Page 1 of 5 ENVIRONMENT IMPACT ASSESSMENT Methodology As identified in the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) currently under preparation, the major environmental problems in Georgia revolve around two major developments: (i) the degradation of natural resources; and (ii) the degradation of the urban environment. An underlying problem/cause of Georgia's environmental troubles is the economic transition, which limits the funding available and continues to exert mounting pressure on scarce natural resources resulting from the inability of the urban areas to meet the physical and social needs. As a result, the cities face the most serious urban environmental problems and require the most urgent attention. In addition, the low quality of public services, principally in infrastructure maintenance, housing, and sanitation, constitute the major areas of urban environmental concern in Georgia. No resettlement will be considered. The impact of these environmental problems on health has not been recently assessed, but it is clear that inadequate sanitation facilities contribute significantly to the prevalence of infectious diseases. Poor provision of infrastructure is particularly hindering economic activities. These factors particularly affect the urban poor and threaten to undermine the very foundations of the productive and service economies of the country. In order to maximize the impact of the whole project on the urban environment, the project proposes a simplfied methodology for assessing the environmental impact of the subprojects financed by the MDF. The standardized environmental impact assessment for every subproject will be included in the Manual of Procedures. This methodology will be used by the beneficiaries in the process of identifying subprojects to be financed through the project. The proposed methodology should help the beneficiaries in assessing the positive impact and reducing or eliminating the negative impact of each subproject on the urban environment. The MDF's projects in the areas of sanitation and cleaning of urban drainage, urban renewal, road maintenance, garbage collection, school and clinic rehabilitation will lead to significant improvements in the urban environment. Particular attention has been given to the need for a fruitful cooperation between the MDF and the Ministry of Environment. The annual technical audits will also include an environmental component. In addition, for the mid-term review, the PCU will commission an assessment of the environmental impact of the subprojects carried out during the first half of the project. This review will examine all major environmental issues to determine their impact and make recommendations on how to mitigate any adverse impacts in the future.

 MDDP 71 Annex ll Page I of 4 SYNOPSIS OF OPERATIONAL MANUAL Introduction 1. The purpose of the Operational Manual is to provide the necessary guidelines to the municipalities, PCU, MDF and CMCs for executing the project smoothly and systematically. It contains instructions pertaining to each of the noted below chapters pertaining to the project. 1. General Ethical Principles Applicable to the PCU and the MDF 2. MDF's (Municipal Development Fund) Role, Functions and Responsibilities 3. PCU's (Project Coordination Unit), Role, Functions and Responsibilities 4. CMC's (Contract Management Unit), Role, Functions and Responsibilities 5. Municipalities and Sub-Projects Selection Methodology 6. Procurement Guidelines and Procedures 7. Project Implementation 8. Accounting Procedures and Auditing 9. Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting 10. Administrative Procedures 2. The manual is organized in such a manner that it fully addresses all the aspects included in the project. A brief description of each of the chapters is noted as below. 2.1 General Ethical Principles Applicable to the PCU and the MDF: The policies concerning general code of ethical conduct and operating principles while performing the public service are outlined in this section. The employees accordingly, are under an obligation to observe confidentiality, impartiality and a strict discipline in exercising their assigned duties. 2.2 MIF's (Municipal Development Fund) Role, Functions and Responsibilities The Municipal Development Fund will be established by the Presidential Decree as an autonomous legal entity under the supervision of the MDF Board of Directors. The six member Board of Directors will be chosen from the Government and National community. A Charter as prepared by the Regional Policy and Management Service (RPMS) agency is to be attached to the Decree, which would define the role of MDF. The main responsibilities of the MDF unit in working with the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and Contract Management Unit (CMC), include: assist the municipalities preparing their Municipal Contract (MC); carry out the financial and economic analysis of the municipal proposals and prepare the appraisal documents for presentation to the MDF Board; maintain the sub-loan accounts. Additionally, the MDF will work in close cooperation with the MoF in order to coordinate municipal and regional finance policies, issue tax and levies management procedures, manage the intergovernmental fiscal relationship, program central government transfers to municipalities, prepare budgeting guidelines and directives, propose equalization policy, define municipal accounting standards, standardize payment procedures, etc. Within this broad framework, the MDF provide resources, and supervise local government investment activities.
 MDDP 72 Annex 11 Page 2 of 4 2.3 PCU's (Project Coordination Unit), Role, Functions and Responsibilities The Project Coordination Unit (PCU), will be responsible for the implementation of MDDP's institutional development component. PCU is to be established through a draft charter attached to the Presidential Decree. The PCU will work with MDF to accomplish the project's development objectives. The Operational Manual will elaborate the role, responsibilities, and structure of the Unit in accordance with the guidelines provided in the PCU Charter. The PCU will function under the supervision of the Head of RPMS and will be accountable to the President of Georgia and the Investment Council. 2.4 CMC's (Contract Management Consultant), Role, Functions and Responsibilities The procurement of goods, works and consultant services, needed for the investment component of the project will be contracted out by the MDF and PCU to the independent Contract Management Consultants (CMC). Once a sub-project is approved by the MDF Board, it will be handed over to CMC. The CMC would be selected through a competitive process on the basis of their experience with the Bank financed projects. With the assistance of appropriate experts, CMC will be responsible for contract administration on behalf of the MDF and the concerned municipalities. The work scope will include: (i) training of municipal, MDF, and PCU staff and developing monitoring procedures for the municipalities to be used in managing procurement and disbursement; (ii) detailing of procurement plan for the sub-projects; (iii) preparing technical specifications of material and equipment required; (iv) preparing specific bid documents based on the Bank SBDs; (v) preparing TORs for hiring consultant services, etc. The detailed terms of reference for CMC would be provided in the Operational Manual. 2.5 Municipalities and Sub-Projects Selection Methodology The selection of municipalities and sub-projects under the physical investment component under MDDP, will be articulated around a Municipal Development Agreement, a binding agreement between the central government and municipalities. To initiate, a Municipality will do the following: (a) submit a request to the Department of Local Government's Project Coordination Unit, expressing their interest in Project Approach; (b) complete an audit to determine the financial capacity of the municipality, and identifying the administrative, financial and technical action-plan selected for the Local Adjustment Plan; and (c) propose a Priority Investment Plan, with the selection of the municipal top-priorities and its impact on the local budget. To achieve the objectives of the project, for screening the noted below selection criteria was applied: (ai) demonstrated willingness to perform; (b) basic financial and administrative capacity; and (c) above average management capabilities; The 10 regional representatives proposed a total of 23 municipalities to RPMS and the Bank for initial consideration. Based on the criteria above 11 municipalities were selected to be benefited from the project.
 MDDP 73 Annex I1 Page 3 of 4 The subsequent actions on the part of the selected municipalities, MDF, PCU and CMC would include: (i) the municipal audit will be executed by local consultants; (ii) preparation of the financial and administrative rehabilitation plan by the respective municipalities; (iii) preparation of priority investment plan of the municipalities. Thereafter, MDF will carry out: (a) review of the financial situation of the municipalities, (b) highlight where the gaps are in terms of maintenance, services, and infrastructure, and (c) justify the investments selected under the priority investment plan; and (d) the preparation of municipal contracts for 11 qualified municipalities. If any of the first 11 selected municipalities fails to qualify, would be replaced by any of the 12 reserve municipalities. The standard Forms for: Municipal Audit; Financial and Rehabilitation Plan; Priority Investment Project; Municipal Development Agreement; and Sub-Projects Screening Methodology are provided in the Operational Manual for guidance. 2.6 Procurement Guidelines and Procedures Procurement Guidelines and Procedures, provide necessary guidelines on the Bank's standard procurement procedures as applied to the specific requirements of MDDP. Broadly, it contains the procurement arrangements, for the two categories: (i) a line of credit for $16.00 million to Georgian Municipalities through the MDF; and (ii) the Institutional component for $4.5 million, covering the various studies and consulting services, including small equipment items for PCU and MDF use. The procurement procedures to be followed by the MDF and CMC for the priority investment component and by PCU for the institutional development component will be provided in the Operational Manual. 2.7 Project Implementation The project will be implemented through three main entities: PCU; MDF; and CMC. The Operational Manual describes the functions and operational responsibilities of each of these entities in detail. Other municipalities qualified for participating in the project; (ii) organization and management improvement, including improvement of services to the public, development of simplified administrative procedures; (iii) strengthening municipal planning and programming procedures; (iv) human resource planning, including the development of a career and incentives structure within municipalities, the definition of training needs; and (v) physical investment project implementation management. 2.8 Accounting Procedures and Auditing The MDDP accounting system and the procedures are to be clearly defined in the accounting section of the Operational Manual. The MDDP Accounting Department will be responsible for maintaining an adequate control of the accounting information that will be registered in the accounting system by the qualified staff members. The Department shall be responsible for keeping all supporting documentation required by normal accounting practices for payments made to finance the approved projects or administrative expenses. The audit will be carried out in accordance International Standards on Auditing and will include such tests and controls as the auditor considers necessary in the circumstances.
 MDDP 74 Annex 1I Page 4 of 4 Monthly Statements, are to prepared regularly and issued to the agreed Governmental and donors, including to World Bank. Reporting obligations and auditing procedures and schedules are defined in the manual. 2.9 Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting Project monitoring will be the responsibility of PCU, contracting out most of these functions, as appropriate. PCU will furnish the Bank with reports on a regular basis including: (i) quarterly progress and project financial management reports; (ii) interim unaudited statements of project accounts kept by PCU; and (iii) additional information that the Bank may request from time to time. PCU's financial statements will also be provided annually. The complete reporting requirements will be described in the Operational Manual. Performance monitoring will be undertaken by the Bank. To ensure close monitoring of the achievements of project objectives during implementation, a set of key performance indicators have been developed. As this is the first Bank-supported investment credit primarily in the rural sector, the project is expected to require a significant supervision effort. Reporting requirements regarding: selection of sub-projects; implementation status; awarding of contracts for works, goods and services; disbursement status; technical assistance; and distribution names will be spelled out in the Operation Manual. 2.10 Administrative Procedures These procedures pertain to: (i) Personnel Hiring Procedures; (ii) Office Management Policies; and (iii) Staff evaluation and Governing Procedures; for PCU and MDF will be described in the Operational Manual. The guidelines will be administered in accordance with the procedures stated in the Operational Manual. The Executive Director is nominated and confirmed by the State Investment Council. The PCU will function under the supervision of the Head of RPMS. The Head of PCU is also nominated by the State Investment Council and would be responsible for hiring the needed personnel on a competitive basis in accordance with the TOR for each position. All employees are hired on a contractual basis on a one-year renewable term, with a three- month probation period. Two months before the expiration of the contract, the Executive Committee will evaluate the performance of each staff member, and on the basis of this appraisal, decide whether the contract can be extended for another year. All staff regulations are to be in compliance with the existing labor legislation of Georgia.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Municipal Development and Decentralization Project are to: (1) assist the decentralization process at the central and local government level; (2) promote an improvement of financial and administrative management as well as municipal investment program; (3) support urgent local investments; and (4) generate employment opportunities. The first of the two main components, Institutional Development, has two subcomponents: (1) helping to implement a municipal development program centered on binding agreements (MDAs) between the central government and participating municipalities to improve organization and management, including public services delivery, strengthen municipal planning and programming procedures, human resource planning, and physical investment project implementation management, and (2) strengthening the central government's capacity to implement effectively the planned decentralization program by developing national information systems, analyzing policy alternatives, evaluating the impact of regional and sector investments on municipal finance, establishing a project coordinating unit, and supporting the initial investment and operating costs of the Municipal Development Fund (MDF). The second component, Physical Investments, will finance municipal investments listed in the Priority Investment Plan (PIP). Investments include construction rehabilitation and maintenance of public infrastructure (primary and secondary facilities) and services operated by local government, such as roads, drainage, lighting, etc.; water supply, sanitation, and solid waste management; revenue generating facilities; health and school facilities; and rehabilitation of historic properties.
